content:
**TRUE.** The statement is factual. A new tarantula species named *Chilobrachys natanicharum*, characterized by a rare electric blue coloration, was officially described in 2023 after being found in the mangrove forests of Thailand[1][2][3].

## Summary of Discovery

Researchers from Khon Kaen University and the Natural History Museum of the National Science Museum, alongside wildlife YouTuber JoCho Sippawat, formally identified the species *Chilobrachys natanicharum* in its natural habitat in southern Thailand[4][5][6]. The discovery was inspired by the team's 2022 finding of the bamboo culm tarantula (*Taksinus bambus*)[1][2][5]. While the species was already present in the commercial tarantula trade under the name “Chilobrachys sp. Electric Blue Tarantula,” it lacked formal scientific documentation regarding its natural habitat or unique traits until this research[2][7][8].

### Official Designation and Naming
The formal scientific description of *Chilobrachys natanicharum* was published in the journal *ZooKeys* on September 18, 2023[7][3][9][10]. The species belongs to the genus *Chilobrachys* within the family *Theraphosidae*[9].

The specific name, *natanicharum*, was chosen through an auction campaign[2][11]. The winning bidder, Nichada Properties Co., Ltd., named the tarantula after two of its executives, Mr. Natakorn Changrew and Ms. Nichada Changrew[1][2][5]. Proceeds from the auction were donated to support the education of Lahu children in Thailand and to aid cancer patients[12][13][14].

### Discovery and Habitat
The tarantula was discovered in the mangrove forests of Phang-Nga province in southern Thailand[1][12]. This marked the first time any tarantula species has been found living in Thailand's mangrove forests[9][5][16]. The spiders inhabit hollow trees, which makes them difficult to capture, requiring researchers to climb trees in humid and slippery conditions to lure them out[1][17]. The species demonstrates adaptability by living in both arboreal and terrestrial burrows in evergreen forests, but in mangrove forests, its habitat is restricted to tree hollows due to tidal influence[18][9]. Specimens were collected at elevations ranging from 5 to 57 meters above sea level[9][3].

### Physical Characteristics and Coloration
*Chilobrachys natanicharum* is known for its "mesmerizing blue-violet hue, reminiscent of electric blue sparks"[12][11]. The iridescent coloration appears on its legs, chelicerae (mouthparts), and carapace (back)[16][19].

The unique color is not created by pigments but is a structural color[11][20]. It results from nanostructures in the spider's hair that manipulate light to reflect high-energy blue light[6][21]. This phenomenon, which has evolved independently in tarantulas at least eight times, is similar to that seen in peacock feathers[9][11].

Coloration varies by sex and age:
*   **Males** have more prominent metallic-blue hairs and black carapaces[4][23].
*   **Females and young males** have more violet than metallic-blue hairs, and females have metallic-blue and violet hairs interspersed across their carapaces[4][23].

Adult male specimens collected by researchers ranged from approximately 1.51 to 2.19 inches (3.8 to 5.6 cm), while females measured between 2.24 and 2.66 inches (5.7 to 6.8 cm)[7][23].

### Rarity and Conservation
The species is considered rare for several reasons. The electric blue coloration itself is an exceptionally rare phenomenon in nature[9][11][20]. Furthermore, the tarantula's primary habitat in mangrove forests is under threat from deforestation[1]. Due to the loss and destruction of its habitat, the species is listed by Thailand as controlled wildlife[9]. One report describes it as one of the world's rarest tarantulas because of this habitat decline[24].
